posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
David, in reply to your first comment:

It's possible, but it makes no sense. I really think you should read the guide I referred you to. There's A LOT of info there that you'll find useful. There are also some class guides you can take a look at. I wrote a Paladin guide, for example, which you can benefit A LOT from if you take the time to read it. The problem is that I understand where you're at, you're missing a lot of information and you are EXTREMELY server-biased in your NWN conceptions, probably because you've been playing at the same place for a long time. You know everything there is to know about your server, all the items, cool bosses, requirements, subraces, etc... But there is a whole new world out there that will increase your awareness of the game as a whole and even improve on what you already know about your server. In other words, you can use the knowledge you acquire here in combination with your knowledge of the server you play to come up with better optimized characters that are exceptionally well-tweaked for that environment.

As for the Paladin / CoT, please make another topic for it, as this is the Monk / SD one, and we are FAR off topic. Thanks!

As for the second comment, I think I can explain:

EVERY POINT YOU PUT IN CON is one less point you put somewhere else. Having high CON by itself isn't bad, what's bad is what you trade it for. Let's take a look at two different situations for you to try to understand what I mean:

1- A Fighter / Dwarven Defender / Rogue (12 / 26 / 2). Dwarven Defenders get DR as a class feature, and with 26 levels, they'll have 18 points of damage reduction just for having those class levels. They also receive d12 hit points and they have Defensive Stance (which increases their CON and AC as long as they don't move). They are also immune to Sneak Attack. So, they are DAMAGE-SOAKING MACHINES!! They have very high HPs, and with the EDR feats, they'll have 27 points of DR, PLUS A BELT OF DAMAGE RESISTANCE, that makes them nearly impervious to damage.

2- A Paladin / COT - Paladins add CHARISMA to their saves, they also have Divine Might and Divine Shield to add CHARISMA as Damage and AC, they have CHARISMA buffs to increase their modifier, they have Smite Evil, which adds CHARISMA to their attack roll and class level to damage against evil. CoTs have Divine Wrath, which lasts a number of rounds equal to CHARISMA modifier. Harper Scouts get Great Charisma as a bonus feats, and CoTs have Great Smiting, which requires 25 CHARISMA as a requirement.

Looking at these two examples it's pretty obvious where the EDR feats have better synergy, right? What you need to understand is that NO BUILD IS GOOD AT EVERYTHING. You cant be a high-AB-high-AC-damage-dealing-epic-casting-dev-critting-immune-to-criticals-high-HP-High-DR-spell-resistant-high-saves character. So, you will ALWAYS be faced with Strengths x Weaknesses of the build. As a rule of thumb, optimizing a build means maximizing strengths and minimizing weaknesses. Adding EDR to the first case above, you'll complement the strength of tanking and a high fortitude save thanks to 22 CON. If you choose to add it to the second, you'll be significantly lowering the effectiveness of your CHARISMA-based class features for more HP and a little bit of DR, which will make your character good at nothing and therefore WEAK. If you choose to lower WISDOM instead of CHA, you'll lose the ability to cast spells, if you lower STR, you'll lose AB, if you lower DEX (DEX will probably be at 8 already), if you lower INT, you'll lose Skill Points, and the ability to take Expertise (which works WONDERS with Taunt, I'm guessing you don't even use Taunt, right?) and IKD. Basically, CON is one of the least important things in a build like this. Except for DEX, all other attributes are more important than Constitution.

I hope you understand what I'm trying to say.
